critique: This document is an executive order regarding the implementation of the Convention on the Service Abroad of Judicial and Extrajudicial Documents. It designates the Department of State as the Central Authority and specifies other departments to complete certificates related to the convention. The order itself doesn't directly address ideological issues, immigration, or civil liberties. It mainly focuses on the procedural aspects of international legal cooperation. Therefore, most scores should be neutral. There's a slight increase in executive power due to the President's directive, and a slight increase in federalism as it centralizes authority within the federal departments.
